source: Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event , originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television , held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) and later World Championship Wrestling ( WCW ) . From the 1960s to the 1980s , it was tradition for JCP to hold major professional wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas , mostly at Greensboro Coliseum . Starrcade ( 1985 ) was the third annual Starrcade professional wrestling event produced by Jim Crockett Promotions ( JCP ) under the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) banner . Starrcade ( 1987 ) was the fifth annual Starrcade professional wrestling event produced by Jim Crockett Promotions ( JCP ) under the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) banner . Starrcade ( 1997 ) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view ( PPV ) event .
summary:
1. Starrcade was a prominent professional wrestling event that took place annually from 1983 to 2000.
2. Initially, it was broadcast through closed-circuit television and later transitioned to pay-per-view.
3. The event was originally promoted by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
4. Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) held major wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, primarily at Greensboro Coliseum, from the 1960s to the 1980s.
5. The third annual Starrcade event occurred in 1985, the fifth in 1987, and the fifteenth in 1997, all produced by JCP under the NWA banner.

source: Do n't Say No is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun . Seo Ju-hyun ( born June 28 , 1991 ) , known professionally as Seohyun , is a South Korean singer and actress . Apart from her group 's activities , she has established herself as an actress , notably through her participation in the original and Korean versions of stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun , Gone with the Wind and Mamma Mia . 3. Seohyun has also made a name for herself as an actress, particularly in stage musicals such as "Moon Embracing the Sun," "Gone with the Wind," and "Mamma Mia."

5. With this solo debut, she became the third member of Girls' Generation to launch a solo career.

source: The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer , one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products , designed primarily by Steve Wozniak ( Steve Jobs oversaw the development of the Apple II 's foam-molded plastic case and Rod Holt developed the switching power supply ) . The Apple II series ( trademarked with square brackets as `` Apple ] [ '' and rendered on later models as `` Apple / / '' ) is a family of home computers , one of the first highly successful mass-produced text command microcomputer products , designed primarily by Steve Wozniak , manufactured by Apple Computer ( now Apple Inc. ) and introduced in 1977 with the original Apple II . Stephen ( or Stephan ) Gary Wozniak ( [ ˈwɒzniæk ] , born August 11 , 1950 ) , nicknamed `` Woz '' , is an American inventor , electronics engineer , programmer , philanthropist , and technology entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc. .
summary: The Apple II is a pioneering 8-bit home computer that was one of the first widely successful mass-produced microcomputers. It was primarily designed by Steve Wozniak, with Steve Jobs contributing to the design of the foam-molded plastic case and Rod Holt developing the switching power supply. The Apple II series, known for its distinctive "Apple ][" and later "Apple //" trademarks, was introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Steve Wozniak, an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur, is celebrated for co-founding Apple Inc. and his central role in the development of the Apple II.

source: Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and partner Elliot Roberts .
summary: Asylum Records is an American record label that was established in 1971 by David Geffen and his business partner Elliot Roberts. The label has played a significant role in the music industry, particularly in the 1970s and 1990s, by signing and promoting a diverse range of artists across various genres, including rock, pop, and hip-hop. Notably, Asylum Records was the original label for the Eagles, a band that achieved substantial commercial success. The label has undergone several changes in ownership, reflecting the broader trends of consolidation in the music industry. Initially, it was sold to Warner Communications in 1972, and it later became part of the Warner Music Group. In the 1990s, Asylum was relaunched and became a prominent label in the hip-hop genre, particularly with the success of Dr. Dre's "The Chronic." Today, Asylum Records continues to operate as a label under Warner Records, focusing on discovering and nurturing new talent.

source: The Armenian Genocide ( Հայոց ցեղասպանություն , Hayots tseghaspanutyun ) , also known as the Armenian Holocaust , was the Ottoman government 's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians , mostly Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state , the Republic of Turkey . Other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups such as the Assyrians and the Ottoman Greeks were similarly targeted for extermination by the Ottoman government in the Assyrian genocide and the Greek genocide , and their treatment is considered by some historians to be part of the same genocidal policy .
summary:
1. The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was a systematic extermination of approximately 1.5 million Armenians.
2. The victims were primarily Ottoman citizens residing within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey.
3. The genocide was carried out by the Ottoman government.
4. In addition to Armenians, other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups such as the Assyrians and the Ottoman Greeks were also targeted for extermination by the Ottoman government in what is known as the Assyrian genocide and the Greek genocide.
5. Some historians consider the treatment of these groups to be part of the same genocidal policy.

source: The Others (2001 film) . The film won eight Goya Awards , including awards for Best Film and Best Director . The Others was nominated for six Saturn Awards including Best Director and Best Writing for Amenábar and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann , and won three : Best Horror Film , Best Actress for Kidman and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan .
summary: The film "The Others" (2001) achieved significant recognition at the Goya Awards, Spain's national film awards, by winning eight awards, including those for Best Film and Best Director. Notably, it was the first English-language film to win the Best Film Award without containing any Spanish dialogue. Additionally, "The Others" received six Saturn Award nominations, with recognition for Best Director, Best Writing for Alejandro Amenábar, and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann. The film won three Saturn Awards: Best Horror Film, Best Actress for Nicole Kidman, and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan.

source: The 14th Dalai Lama ( [ ˈdɑːlaɪ_ˈlɑːmə ] ( US ) , [ ˌdælaɪ_ˈlɑːmə ] ( UK ) ( religious name : Tenzin Gyatso , shortened from Jetsun Jamphel Ngawang Lobsang Yeshe Tenzin Gyatso , born Lhamo Thondup , 6 July 1935 ) is the current Dalai Lama . The 14th Dalai Lama was born in Taktser village , Amdo , Tibet ( was administratively in Qinghai province , Republic of China ) , and was selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and formally recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama at a public declaration near the town of Bumchen in 1939 . During the 1959 Tibetan uprising , the Dalai Lama fled to India , where he currently lives as a refugee .
summary:
1. The 14th Dalai Lama, known by his religious name Tenzin Gyatso and born as Lhamo Thondup on July 6, 1935, is the current spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism.
2. He was born in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet, which at the time was under the administration of Qinghai province in the Republic of China.
3. In 1937, at the age of two, he was identified as the tulku, or reincarnation, of the 13th Dalai Lama, and this was formally recognized in a public declaration near Bumchen in 1939.
4. Following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, the Dalai Lama escaped to India, where he has lived in exile ever since.

source: Mendicant . Many religious orders adhere to a mendicant way of life , including the Catholic mendicant orders , Hindu ascetics , some dervishes of Sufi Islam , and the monastic orders of Jainism and Buddhism . A monk ( [ mʌŋk ] , from μοναχός , monachos , `` single , solitary '' and Latin monachus ) is a person who practices religious asceticism by monastic living , either alone or with any number of other monks . A monk may be a person who decided to dedicate his life to serving all other living beings , or to be an ascetic who voluntarily chooses to leave mainstream society and live his or her life in prayer and contemplation .
summary:
1. The term "mendicant" refers to a religious way of life followed by various religious orders across different faiths, including Catholicism, Hinduism, Sufi Islam, Jainism, and Buddhism.
2. Monks are individuals who practice religious asceticism through monastic living, which can be done in solitude or in a community with other monks.
3. Monks dedicate their lives to serving others or to asceticism, which involves withdrawing from mainstream society to focus on prayer and contemplation.
4. The word "monk" originates from the Greek word "μοναχός" (monachos), meaning "single" or "solitary," and the Latin word "monachus."

The series followed the lives and missions of three young police officers: Pete Cochran, Julie Barnes, and Linc Hayes, who were recruited by the police force to infiltrate the counterculture and tackle crimes that traditional law enforcement couldn't handle. The Mod Squad was known for addressing contemporary social issues and for its catchphrase, "One black, one white, one blonde."

source: Arizona ( [ ɛərᵻˈzoʊnə , _ ærᵻ - ] ) ( Hoozdo Hahoodzo [ xòːztò xɑ̀xòːtsò ] O'odham : Alĭ ṣonak [ ˡaɺi ˡʃonak ] ) is a state in the southwestern region of the United States . It is the sixth largest and the 14th most populous of the 50 states . Arizona is the 48th state and last of the contiguous states to be admitted to the Union , achieving statehood on February 14 , 1912 . About one-quarter of the state is made up of Indian reservations that serve as the home of 27 federally recognized Native American tribes , including the Navajo Nation , the largest in the state and the United States , with more than 300,000 citizens . Arizona , a state in the southwestern region of the United States of America , is known for its high population of Native Americans .
summary:
1. Arizona is a state located in the southwestern region of the United States.
2. It is the sixth largest state by area and ranks 14th in population among the 50 states.
3. Arizona was the 48th state to join the Union and the last of the contiguous states, gaining statehood on February 14, 1912.
4. Approximately one-quarter of Arizona consists of Indian reservations, which are home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes.
5. The Navajo Nation is the largest Native American tribe in both Arizona and the United States, with over 300,000 citizens.
6. Arizona is notable for its significant Native American population.

source: Human brain . The human brain , with the spinal cord , makes up the central nervous system . The brain consists of the cerebrum , the brainstem and the cerebellum . The cerebrum is the largest part of the human brain . Underneath the cerebral cortex , several important structures are located , including the thalamus , the epithalamus , the pineal gland , the hypothalamus , the pituitary gland , and the subthalamus ; the limbic structures , including the amygdala and the hippocampus ; the claustrum , the various nuclei of the basal ganglia ; the basal forebrain structures , and the three circumventricular organs .
summary:
1. The human brain, along with the spinal cord, constitutes the central nervous system.
2. The brain is composed of three main parts: the cerebrum, the brainstem, and the cerebellum.
3. The cerebrum is the largest region of the brain.
4. Beneath the cerebral cortex, there are several key structures such as the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and subthalamus.
5. The limbic system includes the amygdala and the hippocampus.
6. Other structures located beneath the cerebral cortex are the claustrum, the basal ganglia nuclei, the basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.

source: Sir Donald George `` Don '' Bradman , AC ( 27 August 1908 -- 25 February 2001 ) , often referred to as `` The Don '' , was an Australian cricketer , widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time . Even after he became reclusive in his declining years his opinion was highly sought , and his status as a national icon was still recognised -- more than 50 years after his retirement as a Test player , in 2001 , Prime Minister John Howard of Australia called him the `` greatest living Australian '' .
summary: Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC, born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001, was an Australian cricketer celebrated as the greatest batsman in the history of the sport. Known as "The Don," his exceptional skill and reputation endured long after his retirement from Test cricket. Despite his reclusiveness in later life, his opinions remained highly respected, and his status as a national icon in Australia was undiminished. Over half a century after his retirement, he was still regarded as a preeminent figure, with Australian Prime Minister John Howard referring to him as the "greatest living Australian" in 2001.

source: Margaret Hilda Thatcher , Baroness Thatcher , ( ; 13 October 1925 -- 8 April 2013 ) was a British stateswoman , who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990 . She was the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century , and the first woman to have held the office . In 1975 , Thatcher defeated Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election to become Leader of the Opposition and became the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom .
summary:
1. Margaret Hilda Thatcher, also known as Baroness Thatcher, was a prominent British stateswoman.
2. She served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as the Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990.
3. Thatcher holds the distinction of being the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century.
4. She was the first woman to become the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
5. In 1975, Thatcher won the Conservative Party leadership election against Edward Heath, making her the first woman to lead a major political party in the UK.

source: Baiae ( Baia Baia ) was a mineral springs and coastal resort on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples in ancient Italy . Its ruins are located in the commune of Ercolano , Campania , Italy . Naples . In the immediate vicinity of Naples are numerous culturally and historically significant sites , including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum . Ruins . There are famous ruins all over the world , from ancient sites in China , the Indus valley and Judea to Zimbabwe in Africa , ancient Greek , Egyptian and Roman sites in the Mediterranean basin , and Incan and Mayan sites in the Americas .

2. Herculaneum, an ancient Roman town, was destroyed by volcanic pyroclastic flows from Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. Its ruins are situated in the modern-day commune of Ercolano, within the Campania region of Italy.
3. The area surrounding Naples is rich in historical and cultural sites, including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum.
4. The world is home to numerous famous ruins, spanning various civilizations and eras. These include ancient sites in China, the Indus Valley, Judea, and Zimbabwe, as well as Greek, Egyptian, and Roman ruins in the Mediterranean, and Incan and Mayan ruins in the Americas.

source: Morse code is a method of transmitting text information as a series of on-off tones , lights , or clicks that can be directly understood by a skilled listener or observer without special equipment . To increase the speed of the communication , the code was designed so that the length of each character in Morse varies approximately inversely to its frequency of occurrence in English . Compared to voice , Morse code is less sensitive to poor signal conditions , yet still comprehensible to humans without a decoding device . Many amateur radio repeaters , for example , identify with Morse , even though they are used for voice communications . In an emergency , Morse code can be sent by improvised methods that can be easily `` keyed '' on and off , making it one of the simplest and most versatile methods of telecommunication .
summary:
1. Morse code is a communication method that conveys text through a series of on-off tones, lights, or clicks.
2. It is designed to optimize speed by varying the length of each character inversely to its frequency in English.
3. Morse code is resilient to poor signal conditions and can be understood by humans without decoding equipment.
4. Despite being used for voice communications, amateur radio repeaters often identify with Morse code.
5. Morse code's simplicity and versatility make it ideal for emergency situations, as it can be sent using improvised methods that can be easily keyed on and off.

source: The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake hit northeastern Afghanistan with a magnitude of 6.5 on December 12 at 21:47 ( UTC ) . The Hindu Kush ( [ kʊʃ , _ kuːʃ ] Pashto , Persian and [ ) , also known in Ancient Greek as the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae , is an 800 km mountain range that stretches near the Afghan-Pakistan border , from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan . The Hindu Kush range has numerous high snow-capped peaks , with the highest point in the Hindu Kush being Tirich Mir or Terichmir at 7708 m in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa , Pakistan .
summary: The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake occurred on December 12 with a magnitude of 6.5. It affected northeastern Afghanistan, striking at 21:47 (UTC). The Hindu Kush is an extensive mountain range, approximately 800 km long, that extends from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, running near the Afghan-Pakistan border. This range is characterized by high, snow-capped peaks, with Tirich Mir, located in the Chitral District of Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, being the tallest at 7708 meters. The region is also known historically as the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae.

source: Sean Penn . He has won two Academy Awards , for his roles in the mystery drama Mystic River ( 2003 ) and the biopic Milk ( 2008 ) . Following his film debut in the drama Taps ( 1981 ) and a diverse range of film roles in the 1980s , including Fast Times at Ridgemont High ( 1982 ) , Penn garnered critical attention for his roles in the crime dramas At Close Range ( 1986 ) , State of Grace ( 1990 ) , and Carlito 's Way ( 1993 ) . He became known as a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking ( 1995 ) , for which he earned his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival . Penn received another two Oscar nominations for Woody Allen 's comedy-drama Sweet and Lowdown ( 1999 ) and the drama I Am Sam ( 2001 ) , before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk . His fourth feature film , the biographical drama survival movie Into the Wild ( 2007 ) , garnered critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations .
summary: Sean Penn is an acclaimed actor who has won two Academy Awards. His first Oscar was for his role in the mystery drama "Mystic River" (2003), and the second was for his portrayal in the biopic "Milk" (2008). Penn's acting career began with his film debut in "Taps" (1981), and he took on a variety of roles throughout the 1980s, including in "Fast Times at Ridgemont High" (1982). He gained critical attention for his performances in the crime dramas "At Close Range" (1986), "State of Grace" (1990), and "Carlito's Way" (1993). Penn established himself as a leading actor with "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and winning the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received additional Oscar nominations for his roles in Woody Allen's "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and the drama "I Am Sam" (2001). Penn also directed the biographical drama "Into the Wild" (2007), which received critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

source: History of Earth . Volcanic outgassing probably created the primordial atmosphere and then the ocean ; but the atmosphere contained almost no oxygen and so would have been toxic to most modern life including humans . Over time , the Earth cooled , causing the formation of a solid crust , and allowing liquid water to exist on the surface . The process of plate tectonics continues to play a dominant role in the shaping of Earth 's oceans and continents and the living species they harbor . Changes in the biosphere -- now dominated by human activity -- continue , in turn , to produce significant effects on the atmosphere and other systems of the Earth 's surface , such as the integrity of the ozone layer , the proliferation of greenhouse gases , the conditions of productive soils and clean air and water , and others . Water . Water covers 71 % of the Earth 's surface .
summary:
1. Volcanic outgassing likely formed the early atmosphere and oceans on Earth, with an atmosphere lacking oxygen and toxic to most current life forms, including humans.
2. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, allowing for the existence of liquid water on the surface.
3. Plate tectonics have been instrumental in shaping Earth's oceans, continents, and the life forms they support.
4. Human activities now dominate changes in the biosphere, significantly impacting the atmosphere and other Earth surface systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gas concentrations, and the quality of soil, air, and water.
5. Water is a significant feature of Earth, covering 71% of its surface.

source: Martin Van Buren ( Maarten van Buren ; December 5 , 1782 -- July 24 , 1862 ) was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States ( 1837 -- 41 ) . A member of the Democratic Party , he served in a number of other senior roles , including eighth Vice President ( 1833 -- 37 ) and tenth Secretary of State ( 1829 -- 31 ) , both under Andrew Jackson . Van Buren was a major supporter and organizer for Jackson in the 1828 election , and ran for Governor of New York in the hope of using his personal popularity to boost Jackson 's campaign . Jackson and Van Buren were elected , and after serving as governor for two months , Van Buren resigned to become Jackson 's Secretary of State . In 1831 , following his resignation as Secretary of State , which aided Jackson in resolving the Petticoat affair , Jackson gave Van Buren a recess appointment as American minister to Britain .
summary: Martin Van Buren was an American politician and a member of the Democratic Party who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. Prior to his presidency, he was the eighth Vice President from 1833 to 1837 and the tenth Secretary of State from 1829 to 1831, both under President Andrew Jackson. Van Buren played a key role in Jackson's 1828 election, running for Governor of New York to bolster Jackson's campaign. After Jackson's victory, Van Buren served as governor for a brief two months before resigning to become Jackson's Secretary of State. His resignation from this position was part of the resolution to the Petticoat affair. Later, in 1831, Jackson gave Van Buren a recess appointment as the American minister to Britain. Throughout his career, Van Buren was a significant supporter and organizer for Jackson.

He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017 , having previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 , and the British middleweight title in 2016 . As of May 2017 , Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world 's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec , Also he is ranked as the seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board .
summary:
1. Christopher Livingstone Eubanks, known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998.
2. Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr., the son of Chris Eubank, is also a British professional boxer.
3. Eubank Jr. has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017.
4. He previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016.
5. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec.
6. He is also ranked as the seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

source: Human trafficking is the trade of humans , most commonly for the purpose of forced labour , sexual slavery , or commercial sexual exploitation for the trafficker or others . According to the International Labour Organization ( ILO ) , forced labor alone ( one component of human trafficking ) generates an estimated $ 150 billion in profits per annum as of 2014 . Of these , 14.2 million ( 68 % ) were exploited for labor , 4.5 million ( 22 % ) were sexually exploited , and 2.2 million ( 10 % ) were exploited in state-imposed forced labor .
summary:
1. Human trafficking involves the trade of humans primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation.
2. The International Labour Organization (ILO) reported that forced labor, a component of human trafficking, yields approximately $150 billion in annual profits as of 2014.
3. The ILO also estimated that out of the total victims:
   - 68% (14.2 million) were subjected to labor exploitation.
   - 22% (4.5 million) were sexually exploited.
   - 10% (2.2 million) were in state-imposed forced labor.

source: Francis I ( Franz Stefan , François Étienne 8 December 1708 -- 18 August 1765 ) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany , though his wife effectively executed the real powers of those positions . Francis I ( François Ier ) ( 12 September 1494 -- 31 March 1547 ) was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois , reigning from 1515 until his death . He was also known as François au Grand Nez ( `` Francis of the Large Nose '' ) , the Grand Colas , and the Roi-Chevalier ( the `` Knight-King '' ) for his personal involvement in the wars against his great rival the Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain Charles V. When this was unsuccessful , he formed a Franco-Ottoman alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent , a controversial move for a Christian king at the time . The Italian war of 1536-1538 was a conflict between King Francis I of France and Charles V , King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor .
summary:
1. Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne) was born on December 8, 1708, and died on August 18, 1765. He held the titles of Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, but his wife was the one who wielded the actual power associated with these positions.

2. A different Francis I (François Ier) from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois was the first King of France from that lineage, ruling from 1515 until his death on March 31, 1547.

3. This Francis I was known by several nicknames: "François au Grand Nez" (Francis of the Large Nose), "Grand Colas," and "Roi-Chevalier" (Knight-King). The latter two reflect his active participation in military campaigns against his chief adversary, Charles V, who was both Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain.

4. When his efforts to oppose Charles V directly were unsuccessful, Francis I pursued a controversial alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, an alliance between a Christian king and a Muslim ruler.

5. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a military conflict between Francis I of France and Charles V, encompassing both his role as King of Spain and as Holy Roman Emperor.

source: Peking University ( abbreviated PKU and colloquially known in Chinese as Běidà 北大 Chinese : 北京大学 , pinyin : Běijīng Dàxué ) , is a major Chinese research university located in Beijing and a member of the C9 League . It is the first modern national university established in China , founded as the Imperial University of Peking in 1898 as a replacement of the ancient Taixue or Guozijian , or Imperial Academy . It also served as the highest administration for education ( ministry of education ) in China at the beginning of its founding . Peking University is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China .
summary:
1. Peking University (PKU), also affectionately known as Beida, is a prestigious research university situated in Beijing, China.
2. It is part of the C9 League, a group of elite Chinese universities.
3. PKU was the first modern national university established in China, founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, succeeding the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, also known as the Imperial Academy.
4. Upon its establishment, it also functioned as the highest educational administration body in China, akin to a ministry of education.
5. Peking University is consistently recognized as the leading institution of higher learning in mainland China.

source: The White House Press Secretary is a senior White House official whose primary responsibility is to act as spokesperson for the executive branch of the United States government administration , especially with regard to the President , senior executives , and policies . The press secretary serves by the appointment of and at the pleasure of the president ; the office does not require the advice and consent of the U.S. Senate , though because of the frequent briefings given to the media , who in turn inform the public , the position is still a very prominent non-Cabinet post .
summary:
1. The White House Press Secretary is a high-ranking official in the White House.
2. Their main role is to serve as the spokesperson for the U.S. government's executive branch, including the President and their administration's policies.
3. The Press Secretary is appointed by the President and can be dismissed by them as well.
4. The position does not require confirmation by the U.S. Senate.
5. Despite this, the role is highly visible and influential due to the frequent briefings provided to the media, which inform the public.
6. Although not a Cabinet position, the White House Press Secretary holds a prominent role in the administration.

source: Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event , originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television , held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) and later World Championship Wrestling ( WCW ) . In 1987 , the WWF scheduled a pay-per-view of their own , Survivor Series , on Thanksgiving night and demanded exclusivity from cable providers on carriage of the event . From 1987 , Starrcade was broadcast on pay-per-view , the first NWA event to do so . Starrcade (1985) . It aired live on closed-circuit television.In 2014 , the WWE Network included the previous Starrcades ( 1983 -- 1986 ) , which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television , alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section , and rated the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence in the matches , particularly the `` I Quit '' match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum , T.A. . Starrcade ( 1997 ) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view ( PPV ) event .
summary:
1. Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event that began in 1983 and continued until 2000, originally broadcast through closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view.
2. It was initially promoted by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW) after the NWA's involvement.
3. In 1987, the World Wrestling Federation (WWF) scheduled their own pay-per-view, Survivor Series, on Thanksgiving night, the same night as Starrcade, and demanded exclusive carriage from cable providers.
4. As a result, Starrcade began to be broadcast on pay-per-view starting in 1987, making it the first NWA event to do so.
5. The WWE Network, in 2014, included the early Starrcade events from 1983 to 1986, which were previously only available through closed-circuit television, alongside the later pay-per-view events.
6. The WWE Network rated Starrcade events as TV-MA due to the violence in the matches, notably the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A.
7. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth event in the annual series and was a pay-per-view event.

source: The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas at the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27 , 1858 , in Freeport , Illinois . The Lincoln -- Douglas Debates ( also known as The Great Debates of 1858 ) were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln , the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois , and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas , the Democratic Party candidate . The debates in Freeport , Quincy and Alton drew especially large numbers of people from neighboring states , as the issue of slavery was of monumental importance to citizens across the nation .

1. The Freeport Doctrine was formulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates, which took place on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois.
2. The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, consisted of seven debates in total.
3. These debates were between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and Stephen Douglas, the Democratic incumbent senator and Lincoln's opponent.
4. The debates, particularly those in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted large crowds from surrounding states due to the significant national interest in the issue of slavery.

source: Anne Rice ( born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien ; October 4 , 1941 ) is an American author of gothic fiction , Christian literature , and erotica . She began her professional writing career with the publication of Interview with the Vampire in 1976 , while living in California , and began writing sequels to the novel in the 1980s . While reaction to her early works was initially mixed , she became more popular with critics and readers in the 1980s . She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years , from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60 .

The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs .

source: Vietnam ( ˌ ; [ vîət nāːm ] ) , officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam ( SRV ; , is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia . With an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants , it is the world 's 14th-most-populous country , and the ninth-most-populous Asian country . Vietnam is bordered by China to the north , Laos to the northwest , Cambodia to the southwest , Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest , and the Philippines , Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast . Since 2000 , Vietnam 's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world , and , in 2011 , it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies . Vietnam remains one of the world 's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism .
summary:
1. Vietnam is located on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia and is the easternmost country in the region.
2. It has an estimated population of 92.7 million, making it the 14th most populous country globally and the 9th most populous in Asia.
3. Vietnam is bordered by several countries: China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and has maritime borders with Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia.
4. Since the year 2000, Vietnam has experienced one of the highest economic growth rates in the world.
5. In 2011, Vietnam topped the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies.
6. Vietnam is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.

source: James VI and I ( 19 June 1566 -- 27 March 1625 ) was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from the union of the Scottish and English crowns on 24 March 1603 until his death . The kingdoms of Scotland and England were individual sovereign states , with their own parliaments , judiciary , and laws , though both were ruled by James in personal union . He was a major advocate of a single parliament for England and Scotland . 3. James was a proponent of unifying the parliaments of England and Scotland into a single legislative body.
4. During his time as king of England, James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, encountered significant challenges in his relations with the English Parliament.

source: Speech recognition ( SR ) is the inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies that enables the recognition and translation of spoken language into text by computers . It incorporates knowledge and research in the linguistics , computer science , and electrical engineering fields . Speech recognition applications include voice user interfaces such as voice dialing ( e.g. `` Call home '' ) , call routing ( e.g. `` I would like to make a collect call '' ) , domotic appliance control , search ( e.g. find a podcast where particular words were spoken ) , simple data entry ( e.g. , entering a credit card number ) , preparation of structured documents ( e.g. a radiology report ) , speech-to-text processing ( e.g. , word processors or emails ) , and aircraft ( usually termed Direct Voice Input ) . The advances are evidenced not only by the surge of academic papers published in the field , but more importantly by the worldwide industry adoption of a variety of deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems . These speech industry players include Google , Microsoft , IBM , Baidu , Apple , Amazon , Nuance , SoundHound , IflyTek , CDAC many of which have publicized the core technology in their speech recognition systems as being based on deep learning .
summary:
1. Speech recognition (SR) is a subset of computational linguistics that focuses on the development of technologies to convert spoken language into text.
2. It is an interdisciplinary field that combines linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.
3. SR has practical applications in various areas such as voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing and call routing, control of domotic appliances, search functions for spoken words, data entry, structured document preparation like radiology reports, speech-to-text for word processing or emails, and aircraft control through Direct Voice Input.
4. The progress in SR is indicated by the increasing number of academic publications and, more significantly, by the adoption of deep learning methods by the speech recognition industry worldwide.
5. Major industry players, including Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, have acknowledged that their speech recognition systems are based on deep learning technology.

source: Richard Alf ( January 26 , 1952 -- January 4 , 2012 ) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970 . San Diego Comic-Con . It was founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans that included Shel Dorf , Richard Alf , Ken Krueger and Mike Towry ; later , it was called the `` San Diego Comic Book Convention '' .
summary: Richard Alf was an American businessman and former comic book store owner, born on January 26, 1952, and passed away on January 4, 2012. He was a co-founder of the San Diego Comic-Con International, which he helped establish in 1970 and served as its chairman. The event, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, was created by a group from San Diego, including Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. Over time, the convention's name evolved to the "San Diego Comic Book Convention" before becoming known as the San Diego Comic-Con International.

source: Fist of Legend . It is a remake of the 1972 Fist of Fury , which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character .
summary:
1. "Fist of Legend" is a remake.
2. The original film, "Fist of Fury," was released in 1972.
3. Bruce Lee played the lead role in the original "Fist of Fury."
4. "Fist of Legend" features a new actor in the role originally played by Bruce Lee.
5. The remake updates the story and characters from the original film.

source: France's Dubuisson carded a 67 to tie with overnight leader Van Zyl of South Africa on 16 under par. McIlroy carded a third straight five under-par 67 to move to 15 under par with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. The world number three's round included an eagle on the 12th as he bids to win his first title since May. "The 67s I've shot this week have all been a little different and I feel like I've played within myself for all of them, " said four-time major winner McIlroy of Northern Ireland. "I feel there's a low round out there for me and hopefully it's tomorrow." McIlroy was level par for the day after 10 holes, dropping his first shots of the week by three-putting the third and 10th, the latter mistake prompting the 26-year-old to throw his putter at his bag. But he hit back with a birdie on the par-five 11th and a towering four iron from 229 yards on the 13th set up an eagle from just four feet. The former world number one ruptured a ligament in his left ankle during a game of football with friends in July, ruling him out of several tournaments. But he returned in time to unsuccessfully defend his US PGA title at Whistling Straits in August and played in three of the FedEx Cup play-off events before starting the new PGA Tour season with a tie for 26th in the Frys.com Open in California. He is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads England's Danny Willett by 271, 214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open. English pair Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12) who were tied for second overnight are fifth and seventh respectively.
summary: Victor Dubuisson of France shot a 67 to join overnight leader Jaco Van Zyl of South Africa at the top of the leaderboard at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy, ranked world number three, also carded a 67 for the third consecutive round, placing him at 15 under par alongside Kiradech Aphibarnrat of Thailand. McIlroy's round featured an eagle on the 12th hole, and he expressed confidence in his ability to post a low score in the upcoming round. Despite a slow start and a couple of three-putts, McIlroy recovered with a birdie on the 11th and an eagle on the 13th after a strong four iron shot. McIlroy, a four-time major winner from Northern Ireland, is aiming for his first victory since May and is in contention for a third Race to Dubai title, leading Danny Willett by 271, 214 points with three events left after the Turkish Open. Other notable players include Englishmen Chris Wood and Richard Bland, who are in fifth and seventh place respectively. McIlroy's recent return to golf follows a July injury where he ruptured a ligament in his left ankle, causing him to miss several tournaments. He managed to compete in the US PGA title defense and some FedEx Cup play-off events before his tie for 26th in the Frys.com Open.

source: Sheikh Ali Salman told the BBC that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government had to show its willingness to offer "concrete solutions". "We want someone who can speak for the royal family," he said. Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa is seen as a reformist in a court divided on how to respond to opposition demands. Hardliners - centred around the unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, who has been in his post since 1971 - are said to be opposed to a dialogue process which has only just been agreed between the government and six opposition societies. They fear that any concessions will only serve to encourage more demands from opposition leaders they deeply distrust. However, speaking to the BBC during a visit to London, Sheikh Salman insisted that now was the time for dialogue. "We welcome it, we are ready for it," he said. "We believe that dialogue and negotiations are necessary." The al-Wefaq leader acknowledged that many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties. "A lot of young people do not believe that we should ask for permission to go on a demonstration, or that we should call for a constitutional monarchy with this family, which until now is still killing people". But he believed that the only way forward was to work with reformists within the Sunni Muslim royal family, including the US- and UK-educated Crown Prince Salman, who has has long been considered a proponent of accommodation with the country's Shia majority. Sheikh Salman noted that hours before King Hamad brought in Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) troops to restore order and crush dissent on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan that would have moved Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy. "We had an agreement with the crown prince," he said. "The seven principles were announced and then 12 hours later, GCC troops came in and severed the dialogue." Asked about the appointment of Senator John Kerry as US secretary of state, Sheikh Salman said he was "hopeful" that he would "do more than his predecessor", Hillary Clinton. "US policy needs to be more clear and direct. The United States government needs to pressure harder for human rights and democratic practices.  We are told that Mr Kerry has more interest in Bahrain and so we hope he will achieve more." On the UK's approach to the crisis in Bahrain, the al-Wefaq leader was more blunt. "If the UK government and [Prime Minister David] Cameron are serious about putting an end to violence and human rights abuses, then they have to speak out publically. "It is not enough to say: 'We are privately urging reform.' That has been done for years. Unfortunately, the Bahrain government is not listening to these private conversations. "So, the question I would ask the British government is: 'Shall you continue to say it privately and not put public pressure?' This is not, I think, a good policy." Sheikh Salman also reiterated al-Wefaq's position that it would continue to call for "peaceful demonstrations", even though all public gatherings and rallies are currently banned in Bahrain. "It is the only way open to us to put pressure on the government." He also called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been sentenced to between five years and life in prison on evidence widely accepted as having been obtained under torture. They were convicted of plotting to overthrow the government. "These people have a lot of followers in the street.  If they are not part of the dialogue than the dialogue will fail."
summary:
Sheikh Ali Salman, the leader of al-Wefaq, emphasized the need for the Bahraini government to offer concrete solutions and demonstrate willingness for meaningful national dialogue. He called for a representative of the royal family, specifically mentioning Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who is viewed as a reformist, to engage in discussions. The opposition is divided, with hardliners, including the unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, opposing the recently agreed-upon dialogue process, fearing it will lead to more demands.

Despite the loss of faith among young protesters in the opposition parties, Sheikh Salman insisted that dialogue with reformist members of the royal family, such as the Crown Prince, is the only way forward. He referenced a seven-point plan agreed upon with the Crown Prince before the intervention of GCC troops, which would have transitioned Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy.

Sheikh Salman expressed hope that the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, would take a firmer stance on human rights and democratic practices in Bahrain than his predecessor, Hillary Clinton. He criticized the UK's private approach to urging reform in Bahrain and called for public pressure to end violence and human rights abuses.

Al-Wefaq plans to continue organizing peaceful demonstrations despite the ban on public gatherings, as a means to exert pressure on the government. Sheikh Salman also demanded the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists, who were imprisoned on charges of plotting against the government, arguing that their inclusion is crucial for the success of any dialogue.

source: He died at his home in Cambridge following an illness lasting several months, a statement on his website said. It added his funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. Hogwood worked with many leading orchestras around the world and was considered one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement. The conductor founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed the academy across six continents for some 30 years. The AAM also made more than 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Among his most famous recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, which was named by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. His first positions were as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner, and was a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He was the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US. "Christopher had extraordinary generosity of spirit," Christopher Purvis, honorary president of the AAM, said. "He was a great ambassador for historically informed music, the movement of which he was a founder. And he was happy to see the orchestra he founded develop and grow after he stepped down as director." The AAM's music director Richard Egarr added: "I am deeply saddened by the news of Christopher's passing. Christopher provided a fantastic legacy for me to build upon when I joined in 2006 and I know he will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with him." Speaking to Sean Rafferty on Radio 3's In Tune, soprano Dame Emma Kirkby said: "Some of the best players that now lead orchestras all over the world, they started with him. "Chris was a natural academic, an incredibly clever man. He had an amazing capacity to absorb information of all kinds and a really sure sense of how things would be if he really tried to reproduce conditions... a very genial person." David Thomas from Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance, London added: "He always said I want the music to speak for itself because it can, it's good enough, it willâ€¦ a very pleasant and lovely man."
summary:
The passage provides a summary of the life and achievements of Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement exponent, who passed away in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a public memorial service to be announced later. Hogwood was celebrated for his work with numerous prestigious orchestras worldwide. He established the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading the ensemble across six continents for three decades and producing over 200 CDs, notably the first complete Mozart symphonies cycle on period instruments. His acclaimed recordings include a 1980 rendition of Handel's Messiah, which was recognized as one of the greatest recordings by BBC Music Magazine.

Hogwood's musical education included studies with notable figures such as Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova, and Gustav Leonhardt at Cambridge University. He began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London. He held significant positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and the Handel and Haydn Society in Boston, and served as a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary professor at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University.

Tributes to Hogwood highlighted his generosity, his role as a pioneer in historically informed performance, and his influence on the development of the AAM after his directorship. His successor, Richard Egarr, expressed deep sadness and acknowledged Hogwood's significant legacy. Soprano Dame Emma Kirkby and David Thomas from Trinity Laban Conservatoire also praised Hogwood's academic prowess, his ability to let music speak for itself, and his genial personality.

source: In the year to the end of March, 57 victims of homicide (murders and culpable homicides) were recorded - down five on the previous 12 months. This is the lowest number of recorded homicide cases for a single 12-month period since 1976 and half the figure of nine years ago. As of 31 March 2016, only one case of homicide recorded in 2015-16 was unresolved. The report Homicide in Scotland showed that a sharp instrument remained the most common method of killing in Scotland and accounted for 51% of homicides (29 cases) in 2015-16. Nearly all of these cases (26 out of 29) involved a knife. While the majority of the accused had an unknown status for alcohol and drugs, 31% (20 people) were identified by the police as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson said: "While it is encouraging to see continued falls in homicide cases alongside the long-term decline in violent crime, the sustained efforts that have helped achieve this - through education and enforcement - must continue, because each of the lives lost is one life too many. "There is a clear role across a range of public services, in addition to the critical work of our police, to continue to support communities that may remain at risk from violent crime and to challenge irresponsible attitudes both to alcohol misuse and to so-called 'casual' violence. "We will continue to work with partners and invest in a range of projects to help steer our young people away from the risks of a life of violence and crime, while also ensuring our law enforcement agencies and the courts have the powers and resources needed to deal with those who do harm to others." Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker said: "Whilst I welcome the overall downward trend in homicides in Scotland we have to take these statistics with a note of caution. "Last year when the Scottish government were heralding 'record low' homicide figures after a supposed similar drop, the actual figures were being revised upwards to show an increase. "Meanwhile, sexual crime in Scotland sits at a 45-year high and in the past year we have seen an increase in violent crime with attempted murder and serious assault rising by a staggering 27%." The number of homicide victims for 2014-15 stood at 59 last year but later increased to 62, after three cases were reclassified following deaths.
summary:
1. In the year leading up to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. This figure represents a significant decline compared to nine years prior.

2. By March 31, 2016, only one of the homicide cases from 2015-16 remained unsolved.

3. The report "Homicide in Scotland" indicated that the most common method of homicide was with a sharp instrument, accounting for 51% of cases (29 victims), with knives being used in 26 of these instances.

4. Of the accused, 31% were found to be under the influence of alcohol or both alcohol and drugs, while the majority had an unknown status regarding substance influence.

5. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson acknowledged the positive trend in the reduction of homicides and violent crime, attributing this to ongoing education and enforcement efforts. He emphasized the need for continued work across various public services to address violent crime and alcohol misuse.

6. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautioned against over-optimism, citing a previous year's revision of homicide figures from a decrease to an increase. She also pointed out that sexual crime was at a 45-year high and that there had been a 27% increase in violent crimes such as attempted murder and serious assault in the past year.

7. The homicide count for 2014-15 was initially reported as 59 but later revised to 62 after three additional cases were reclassified as homicides following deaths.

source: The Cherries went down 2-1 at Sunderland on Saturday, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling's goal, which gave them the lead, was their first for three games. "It shouldn't be down to a lack of confidence," Howe told BBC Radio Solent. "We scored six goals against Hull prior to these two games." He continued: "A couple of weeks later, if you were to put the chances we've created together into a clip sequence, the fact that we haven't even scored one goal is difficult to take." Bournemouth were stunned by goals for Sunderland from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty and they were unable to find an equaliser, even against 10 men following Steven Pienaar's dismissal. "We've had enough chances to win three games today," Howe added. "Sometimes football pans out that way and you have to accept it. It's how you move on from that which is key."
summary: The passage describes the outcome of a Premier League match between Sunderland and Bournemouth, which ended with a 2-1 victory for Sunderland. This was Sunderland's first Premier League win of the season. Bournemouth had taken the lead with a goal from Dan Gosling, marking their first goal in three games. Despite this, they were unable to hold onto the lead, conceding goals to Victor Anichebe and a penalty by Jermain Defoe. Bournemouth's manager, Eddie Howe, expressed disappointment in his team's inability to convert chances into goals, noting that they had created enough opportunities to win multiple games. He also mentioned that the team had scored six goals in a previous match against Hull, indicating that a lack of confidence should not have been an issue. Despite Sunderland being reduced to 10 men after Steven Pienaar's sending off, Bournemouth could not capitalize and find an equalizer. Howe emphasized the importance of moving on from the defeat and focusing on future performances.

source: Mr Abbott told Australian media that the only way to prevent people dying at sea was to "stop the boats". Australia detains any migrants trying to reach its shores by boat, and takes them to offshore processing camps to be eventually resettled elsewhere. On Thursday, the New York Times described the policy as "brutal". In an editorial, the newspaper said the "ruthlessly effective" policy was "inhumane, of dubious legality and strikingly at odds with the country's tradition of welcoming people fleeing persecution and war". It said it would be "unconscionable" for European leaders to consider adopting similar policies, as Mr Abbott has previously suggested. Australia has not responded to the editorial, but on Friday Mr Abbott said the image of Syrian three-year-old Alan Kurdi, who died trying to reach Greece by boat with his family, was "very sad". "If you want to stop the deaths, if you want to stop the drownings you have got to stop the boats," he told ABC Radio. "Thankfully, we have stopped that in Australia because we have stopped the illegal boats." On Thursday, Mr Abbott angered Australian Jewish groups by saying the so-called Islamic State (IS), from which many of the migrants to Europe are fleeing, was worse than the Nazis. "The Nazis did terrible evil, but they had a sufficient sense of shame to try to hide it," he told Sydney Radio 2GB. But IS militants, he said, "boast about their evil, this is the extraordinary thing". The Executive Council of Australian Jewry Robert Goot said the comment was "injudicious and unfortunate", saying there was "a fundamental difference between organised acts of terrorism and a genocide systematically implemented by a state as essential policy". "The crimes of Islamic State are indeed horrific but cannot be compared to the systematic round-up of millions of people and their despatch to purpose-built death camps for mass murder," he told Australian media. Mr Abbott later said he stood by his comments, but that he was not in the "business of ranking evil".
summary:
1. Mr Abbott stated that to prevent deaths at sea, the Australian government's policy is to "stop the boats" by detaining migrants attempting to reach Australia by boat and sending them to offshore processing camps for resettlement elsewhere.
2. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "ruthlessly effective," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality," highlighting its contrast with Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. The newspaper also argued that it would be "unconscionable" for European leaders to consider similar measures.
3. Despite the criticism, Mr Abbott maintained his stance, emphasizing that stopping the boats was necessary to prevent drownings, referencing the death of Alan Kurdi, a Syrian three-year-old who died at sea.
4. Mr Abbott also sparked controversy by comparing the so-called Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, stating that while the Nazis tried to hide their atrocities, IS boasts about theirs. This comparison drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups, who argued that the systematic genocide carried out by the Nazis was fundamentally different from acts of terrorism by IS.
5. Although Mr Abbott stood by his comments, he clarified that he was not interested in ranking evil, acknowledging the distinct nature of each.

source: Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying their attacks against civilians. Last week, the US warned it would halt the talks unless Moscow stops bombing the city of Aleppo. Russia said it regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce. Aleppo, Syria's largest city in the north, has come under heavy aerial bombardment since the end of the ceasefire two weeks ago. The main trauma hospital in the rebel-held eastern part of the city was hit in an air strike for the third time in a week, activists said on Monday. Hundreds of people, including children, have died since government forces launched an offensive to take full control of Aleppo after the week-long truce lapsed. Some 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo. In a statement, state department spokesman john Kirby said: "The United States is suspending its participation in bilateral channels with Russia that were established to sustain the cessation of hostilities. "Unfortunately, Russia failed to live up to its own commitments... and was also either unwilling or unable to ensure Syrian regime adherence to the arrangements to which Moscow agreed. "Rather, Russia and the Syrian regime have chosen to pursue a military course," Mr Kirby said, admitting that "this is not a decision that was taken lightly". He said Moscow and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's troops had been "targeting of critical infrastructure such as hospitals, and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians in need, including through the 19 September attack on a humanitarian aid convoy". Moscow strongly denies involvement of its own or Syrian planes in the deadly aid convoy strike, and says the incident was caused by fire on the ground and not by an air strike. In response to the US suspension of the talks, Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said: "We regret this decision by Washington." "Washington simply did not fulfil the key condition of the agreement to improve the humanitarian condition around Aleppo. "After failing to fulfil the agreements that they themselves worked out, they are trying to shift responsibility on to someone else," Ms Zakharova said. She also said that the US had failed to divide jihadist groups in Syria from the moderate opposition. Russia and the US were due to convene in Geneva to try to co-ordinate air strikes against jihadist groups, but American officials were told to return home. The US also said that it would withdraw personnel "that had been dispatched in anticipation of the possible establishment of the Joint (US-Russian) Implementation Centre". However, the two sides would keep talking about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.
summary:
1. The US has suspended talks with Russia regarding the cessation of hostilities in Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians, particularly in Aleppo.
2. The main trauma hospital in rebel-held eastern Aleppo has been hit by air strikes three times in a week, with hundreds of civilians, including children, killed in the offensive to regain control of the city following the collapse of a week-long truce.
3. Approximately 250,000 people are currently trapped in eastern Aleppo.
4. The US State Department, through spokesman John Kirby, accused Russia of not adhering to its commitments and failing to ensure the Syrian regime's compliance with the agreed-upon arrangements, instead choosing to pursue military action.
5. The US also accused Russia and the Syrian regime of targeting critical infrastructure, such as hospitals, and obstructing humanitarian aid.
6. Russia denies involvement in the attack on a humanitarian aid convoy, claiming the incident was due to ground fire rather than an air strike.
7. Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova responded by expressing regret over the US decision and accused the US of not fulfilling its commitment to improve humanitarian conditions around Aleppo and shifting blame for the failed truce.
8. The US and Russia had planned to co-ordinate air strikes against jihadist groups in Geneva, but the US has recalled its officials and withdrawn personnel intended for the potential Joint Implementation Centre.
9. Despite the suspension of talks, the US and Russia will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria to prevent unintended confrontations.

source: Downing Street backed a report by think tank Policy Exchange which said selling high value homes when they become vacant would raise £4.5bn a year. That would be enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes, the report said. Labour said new homes were urgently needed but "driving out hard-working families on low wages from whole neighbourhoods" was not the answer. In its Ending Expensive Social Tenancies report, Policy Exchange argues the move could create the largest social house building programme since the 1970s - giving the economy a kickstart. Neil O'Brien, the think tank's director, told the BBC that social housing would still exist in very expensive areas under its proposal, but there would just be "less of it". "The truth is I don't believe anybody has the right to live in the most expensive parts of town. "People do have a right to get housed, just not in the very most expensive areas," he said. He also suggested that the overall number of people waiting for social housing, currently around 1.8 million, could be reduced by about 500,000 if the scheme was implemented. The prime minister's official spokesman said: "This is something that councils can choose to do already. "Councils should be looking for ways to use their social housing stock as efficiently as they can. The waiting list for social housing has increased a lot over passing years. "They need to think about how they can use that social housing stock efficiently. "If they can sell high-value housing to invest in more social housing and find more homes for more people, then that is certainly something they should look at." But Labour said the coalition's "failed" polices were "making the housing crisis worse not better". Shadow housing minister Jack Dromey said: "Councils and housing associations should make effective use of their housing stock but the government should not force them to arbitrarily sell off social homes, breaking up mixed communities and driving out hard-working families on low wages from whole neighbourhoods." He said the government should use a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes and "put unemployed builders back to work" and boost the construction industry. 'Lucky family' Expensive social housing - which Policy Exchange defines as housing worth more than the average property in each region - accounts for 21.8% of the total social housing stock in the UK, it says. This equates to 816,000 properties - out of a total of 3.78 million - which the think tank says could raise up to £159bn if sold. It says London alone has more than £70bn of expensive social housing. About 3.5% of the total stock becomes vacant every year owing to people moving out or dying, the think tank said. This meant the government could sell a total of 28,500 properties each year, raising £5.5bn a year. The figure would stand at £4.5bn after paying off the debt held against the stock, the report said. Mr O'Brien argued that many hard-working people might want to live in a nicer area or in a bigger house but could not afford to. "Rather than having one lucky family with a very expensive house, you would have two families perhaps desperately waiting for social housing, now having a roof over their heads. "That seems fairer to me," he added. The think tank also said the move would be "extremely popular" with all sections of society, claiming that 73% of people, including social tenants, think people should not be given council houses worth more than the average property in a local authority. 'Dramatic erosion' Critics say such a move would push the least well-off out of expensive streets, and into new ghettos. The National Housing Federation, which represents housing associations, says many towns would be "cleansed" of "hardworking people who can't afford to pay high prices". Labour MP Karen Buck, who represents Westminster North, is concerned that lower income families, particularly in London, will be forced out of more affluent areas creating segregated communities of rich and poor. Ms Buck also argued that the Labour government's £8bn social and affordable housing building programme was cut by 60% when the coalition came to power. Housing Minister Grant Shapps - who is in favour of a sell-off - said the government had introduced "radical reforms" to "get Britain building" and to reduce social housing waiting lists. They included investing £19.5bn public and private funding into an affordable housing programme "set to exceed expectations and deliver up to 170,000 homes". Councils could now offer fixed-term tenancies to new tenants to make sure "social housing goes to those in greatest need", he added.
summary:
The passage discusses a report by think tank Policy Exchange, which proposes selling high-value vacant social homes to fund the construction of new social housing. The report suggests that this could raise £4.5 billion annually, enough to build between 80,000 to 170,000 social homes, potentially the largest social house building program since the 1970s. Policy Exchange's director, Neil O'Brien, argues that while social housing would still exist in expensive areas, there would be less of it, and that no one has the right to live in the most expensive parts of town. He estimates that the scheme could reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000.

Downing Street supports the report, emphasizing that councils already have the option to sell high-value housing to invest in more social housing. The government believes this could help address the growing waiting list for social housing.

However, the Labour Party opposes the idea, stating that the coalition's policies are exacerbating the housing crisis. Shadow housing minister Jack Dromey suggests using a bank bonus tax to fund affordable housing and stimulate the construction industry.

The report defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the regional average, which accounts for 21.8% of the UK's total social housing stock. Policy Exchange estimates that selling 3.5% of the total stock that becomes vacant each year could raise £5.5 billion, or £4.5 billion after debt repayment.

Critics of the proposal worry that it would lead to the displacement of low-income families from affluent areas, creating segregated communities. The National Housing Federation and Labour MP Karen Buck express concerns about the social consequences of such a policy.

In contrast, Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the sell-off, citing the government's investment in affordable housing and the introduction of fixed-term tenancies to prioritize those in greatest need.

In summary, the passage outlines Policy Exchange's proposal to sell vacant high-value social homes to fund new social housing construction, with support from the government and opposition from the Labour Party and housing organizations, who are concerned about the social impact of the policy.

source: Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week at his home in Swansea, the city at the centre of an epidemic of the disease which has reached 942 cases. But the examination was unable to establish whether measles was the main cause of his death. An inquest will be opened and adjourned on Tuesday to allow further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have needed hospital treatment for the illness. Mr Colfer-Williams' mother, Angela Colfer said her son had recently been treated at Swansea's Morriston Hospital for asthma. A few days after he was discharged he became unwell and developed a rash. Mrs Colfer said her son went to see an out-of-hours GP on 17 April with a rash "from head to foot" but not on his arms. The following morning, Mr Colfer-Williams was found dead at his flat. Public Health Wales said on Friday that laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles but further tests were needed to determine the cause of death. The family said they had no idea how Mr Colfer-Williams got measles as no close family member has it, including his three-year-old daughter who has been vaccinated.
summary: 25-year-old Gareth Colfer-Williams from Swansea, the epicenter of a measles outbreak with 942 cases, died last week. The cause of death has not been definitively established, and an inquest has been scheduled for further investigation. The outbreak, which began in November, has led to 83 hospitalizations. Gareth's mother, Angela Colfer, reported that he had been treated for asthma prior to his death. Despite having a rash from head to foot, Gareth was not diagnosed with measles during an out-of-hours GP visit on April 17. He was found dead the next morning at his flat. Public Health Wales confirmed a measles diagnosis through laboratory tests but stated that additional tests are required to ascertain the cause of death. The family is unaware of how Gareth contracted measles since no close family members, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease.

Gateshead defender Liam Hogan superbly blocked Jordan Preston's effort and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted then saved well from Wesley York's shot just before the break. The hosts, who started the second half well, levelled on 62 minutes when a slip by half-time substitute Derek Asamoah let York curl sweetly into the top-right corner from the edge of the box. summary:
The passage provides a summary of a football match between Gateshead and Guiseley in the National League. Guiseley, managed by Adam Lockwood, were unbeaten in five matches, while Neil Aspin's Gateshead had not lost in nine games. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored after a throw-in and assist from James Hurst. In the second half, Gateshead's Derek Asamoah slipped, allowing York to score an equalizer with a curling shot into the top-right corner.
